channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Even a ‘minimal cell’ can grow stronger, thanks to evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02232-1

Exploring evolution in a ‘minimal cell’, and Galaxy-wide gravitational waves.
item.dc:title: Even a ‘minimal cell’ can grow stronger, thanks to evolution
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Regioselective aliphatic C–H functionalization using frustrated radical pairs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06131-3

Regioselective functionalization of aliphatic carbon–hydrogen bonds is achieved using frustrated radical pairs generated from disilazide donors and an N-oxoammonium acceptor.
item.dc:title: Regioselective aliphatic C–H functionalization using frustrated radical pairs
item.dc:creator: Zhipeng Lu
Minsoo Ju
Yi Wang
Jonathan M. Meinhardt
Jesus I. Martinez Alvarado

item.dc:creator: Chao Mao
Xiaoguang Liu
Yuelong Yan

Boyi Gan

item.title: Accurate medium-range global weather forecasting with 3D neural networks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06185-3

Three-dimensional deep neural networks can be trained to forecast global weather patterns, including extreme weather, with accuracy greater than or equal to that of the best numerical weather prediction models.
item.dc:title: Accurate medium-range global weather forecasting with 3D neural networks
item.dc:creator: Kaifeng Bi
Lingxi Xie
Hengheng Zhang
Xin Chen
Xiaotao Gu
Qi Tian

item.title: Therapy-induced APOBEC3A drives evolution of persistent cancer cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06303-1

Induction of APOBEC3A in response to targeted therapies drives evolution of drug-tolerant persister cells, suggesting that its suppression may represent a potential therapeutic strategy in the prevention of acquired resistance to lung cancer targeted therapy.
item.dc:title: Therapy-induced APOBEC3A drives evolution of persistent cancer cells

item.title: Cooperation between bHLH transcription factors and histones for DNA access
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06282-3

Cryo-EM structures and analysis provide insight into the mechanisms by which basic helix–loop–helix transcription factors access E-box DNA sequences that are embedded within nucleosomes, and cooperate with other transcription factors.
item.dc:title: Cooperation between bHLH transcription factors and histones for DNA access

item.title: Remote detection of a lunar granitic batholith at Compton–Belkovich
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06183-5

Measurements from the Chang’e-1 and Chang’e-2 microwave instruments reveal an anomalously hot geothermal source on the Moon that is best explained by a roughly 50-kilometre-diameter granitic system below the geological feature known as Compton–Belkovich.
item.dc:title: Remote detection of a lunar granitic batholith at Compton–Belkovich
item.dc:creator: Matthew A. Siegler
Jianqing Feng
Katelyn Lehman-Franco
Jeffery C. Andrews-Hanna
Rita C. Economos

Timothy D. Glotch
Mackenzie N. White

item.title: Hepatitis C virus RNA is 5′-capped with flavin adenine dinucleotide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06301-3

Hepatitis C virus utilizes flavin adenine dinucleotide as a non-canonical initiating nucleotide for the viral RNA polymerase, resulting in 5′ capping of viral RNA, which provides protection against the host innate immune response.
item.dc:title: Hepatitis C virus RNA is 5′-capped with flavin adenine dinucleotide

item.title: SLC38A2 and glutamine signalling in cDC1s dictate anti-tumour immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06299-8

Competition for glutamine between type-1 conventional dendritic cells and tumour cells has a central role in tuning the anti-tumour immune response and in immune evasion by cancer cells.
item.dc:title: SLC38A2 and glutamine signalling in cDC1s dictate anti-tumour immunity
item.dc:creator: Chuansheng Guo

DHODH inhibitors sensitize to ferroptosis by FSP1 inhibition

item.title: Harnessing a paper-folding mechanism for reconfigurable DNA origami
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06181-7

A method is presented to harness the paper-folding mechanism of reconfigurable macroscale systems to create reconfigurable DNA origami structures, in anticipation that it will advance the development of complex molecular systems.
item.dc:title: Harnessing a paper-folding mechanism for reconfigurable DNA origami
item.dc:creator: Myoungseok Kim
Chanseok Lee
Kyounghwa Jeon
Jae Young Lee
Young-Joo Kim

Hyunsu Kim
Maenghyo Cho
Do-Nyun Kim

item.title: The social value of offsets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06153-x

An analysis proposes the social value of offsets to measure the amount of carbon that should be stored in temporary and risky offsets to compensate one ton of CO2 emissions.
item.dc:title: The social value of offsets
item.dc:creator: Ben Groom
Frank Venmans

item.title: Skilful nowcasting of extreme precipitation with NowcastNet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06184-4

A new nowcasting model unifies physical-evolution schemes and deep-learning methods to accurately predict precipitation with lead times of up to 3 h, including extreme-precipitation events and weather systems that were previously considered intractable with physics-based numerical methods.
item.dc:title: Skilful nowcasting of extreme precipitation with NowcastNet
item.dc:creator: Yuchen Zhang
Mingsheng Long
Kaiyuan Chen
Lanxiang Xing
Ronghua Jin
Michael I. Jordan
Jianmin Wang

item.title: Observation of the orbital Hall effect in a light metal Ti
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06101-9

The orbital Hall effect is observed in the light metal titanium, confirming the orbital Hall effect and indicating that orbital angular momentum is an important degree of freedom in solids.
item.dc:title: Observation of the orbital Hall effect in a light metal Ti
item.dc:creator: Young-Gwan Choi
Daegeun Jo
Kyung-Hun Ko
Dongwook Go
Kyung-Han Kim
Hee Gyum Park
Changyoung Kim
Byoung-Chul Min
Gyung-Min Choi
Hyun-Woo Lee

item.title: Medieval demise of a Himalayan giant summit induced by mega-landslide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06040-5

Observations and samples from the central Himalayas show that a giant rockslide occurring around 1190 ad in the Annapurna massif led to the collapse of an elevated palaeo-summit, illustrating the episodic mode of erosion of the glaciated high relief by mega-rockslides.
item.dc:title: Medieval demise of a Himalayan giant summit induced by mega-landslide
item.dc:creator: Jérôme Lavé

Valery Guillou

Valier Galy

item.title: Evolution of a minimal cell
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06288-x

An engineered minimal cell evolves to escape the negative consequences of genome streamlining.
item.dc:title: Evolution of a minimal cell
item.dc:creator: R. Z. Moger-Reischer
J. I. Glass
K. S. Wise
L. Sun
D. M. C. Bittencourt
B. K. Lehmkuhl
D. R. Schoolmaster Jr

J. T. Lennon

item.title: A rise-to-threshold process for a relative-value decision
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06271-6

The Drosophila egg-deposition motor programme is initiated once a rise-to-threshold process hits a threshold, and subthreshold variation in this process regulates the time spent considering options.
item.dc:title: A rise-to-threshold process for a relative-value decision
item.dc:creator: Vikram Vijayan
Fei Wang
Kaiyu Wang
Arun Chakravorty
Atsuko Adachi
Hessameddin Akhlaghpour
Barry J. Dickson
Gaby Maimon

item.title: Variation in bridgmanite grain size accounts for the mid-mantle viscosity jump
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06215-0

Bridgmanite-enriched rocks in the deep lower mantle of Earth have a larger grain size and higher viscosity than those of the overlying pyrolitic rocks, which explain the mid-mantle viscosity jump.
item.dc:title: Variation in bridgmanite grain size accounts for the mid-mantle viscosity jump
item.dc:creator: Hongzhan Fei
Maxim D. Ballmer
Ulrich Faul
Nicolas Walte
Weiwei Cao
Tomoo Katsura

item.title: The carbon costs of global wood harvests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06187-1

A new model uses time discounting to estimate the present and future carbon costs of global wood harvests under different scenarios, suggesting an underappreciated option to address climate change.
item.dc:title: The carbon costs of global wood harvests
item.dc:creator: Liqing Peng
Timothy D. Searchinger
Jessica Zionts
Richard Waite

item.title: Optimality guarantees for crystal structure prediction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06071-y

An algorithm has been developed that can provably predict the lowest energy structure of crystalline materials using a combination of combinatorial optimization and integer programming.
item.dc:title: Optimality guarantees for crystal structure prediction
item.dc:creator: Vladimir V. Gusev
Duncan Adamson
Argyrios Deligkas
Dmytro Antypov
Christopher M. Collins
Piotr Krysta
Igor Potapov
George R. Darling
Matthew S. Dyer

Matthew J. Rosseinsky

item.title: Loss of CDK4/6 activity in S/G2 phase leads to cell cycle reversal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06274-3

We uncover the mechanism underlying the restriction point phenomenon, suggest a role for cyclin-dependent kinase 4 and 6 activity in S and G2 phases, and explain the behaviour of cells following loss of mitogen signalling.
item.dc:title: Loss of CDK4/6 activity in S/G2 phase leads to cell cycle reversal
item.dc:creator: James A. Cornwell
Adrijana Crncec
Marwa M. Afifi
Kristina Tang
Ruhul Amin
Steven D. Cappell

item.title: Martian dunes indicative of wind regime shift in line with end of ice age
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06206-1

Evidence for a stratigraphic sequence involving initial barchan dune formation, with the transition in wind regime consistent with the end of the ice age is found, compatible with the Martian polar stratigraphic record.
item.dc:title: Martian dunes indicative of wind regime shift in line with end of ice age
item.dc:creator: Jianjun Liu

item.title: Enhanced inner core fine-scale heterogeneity towards Earth’s centre
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06213-2

We create a three-dimensional model of inner core fine-scale heterogeneity, showing that inner core scattering is ubiquitous and that it substantially increases in strength 500–800 km beneath the inner core boundary.
item.dc:title: Enhanced inner core fine-scale heterogeneity towards Earth’s centre
item.dc:creator: Guanning Pang
Keith D. Koper
Sin-Mei Wu
Wei Wang
Marine Lasbleis
Garrett Euler

item.title: ‘We haven’t seen this’: June’s record-smashing temperatures — in data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02219-y

Extreme heat across land and sea has led to disastrous consequences in some regions.
item.dc:title: ‘We haven’t seen this’: June’s record-smashing temperatures — in data
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Light years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02141-3

A line of sight.
item.dc:title: Light years
item.dc:creator: Ayida Shonibar

item.title: The G20 should forge a pact to support nations’ shifts to a low-carbon future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02208-1

Fossil fuels should be used sparingly, in the areas where they contribute most to human welfare.
item.dc:title: The G20 should forge a pact to support nations’ shifts to a low-carbon future
item.dc:creator: Navroz K. Dubash

item.title: Computer algorithms infer gender, race and ethnicity. Here’s how to avoid their pitfalls
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02225-0

Demographic-prediction algorithms have various challenges, following best practices can minimize the harms.
item.dc:title: Computer algorithms infer gender, race and ethnicity. Here’s how to avoid their pitfalls
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey W. Lockhart
Molly M. King
Christin L. Munsch

item.title: How building a phage directory can mean life or death for patients
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02209-0

Jessica Sacher works to develop tools for phage therapy, with the aim of overcoming antimicrobial resistance.
item.dc:title: How building a phage directory can mean life or death for patients
item.dc:creator: Andy Tay

item.title: Nanoscale origami with DNA-wireframe paper
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02022-9

Origami — the art of making various shapes from a single piece of paper — has been realized at the nanoscale using DNA. Sheets of ‘DNA wireframe paper’ have been developed that, through folding along crease lines, can be transformed into a range of target shapes in response to external stimuli.
item.dc:title: Nanoscale origami with DNA-wireframe paper

item.title: A lack of commitment to proliferation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02136-0

It turns out that commitment to cell division is not an irreversible switch. In the absence of sustained stimulation by growth factor proteins during DNA replication, cells can quit the cell cycle before cell division occurs.
item.dc:title: A lack of commitment to proliferation
item.dc:creator: Alexis R. Barr

item.title: First light on orbitronics as a viable alternative to electronics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02072-z

An effect that transfers information using the rotational motion of electrons has been detected with light, forging a path towards technologies that are cheaper — and less harmful to the environment — than existing electronics.
item.dc:title: First light on orbitronics as a viable alternative to electronics
item.dc:creator: Tatiana G. Rappoport

item.title: Disinformation researchers under investigation: what’s happening and why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02195-3

US researchers have spent years studying how conspiracy theories spread. Now they are accused of helping to suppress conservative opinions.
item.dc:title: Disinformation researchers under investigation: what’s happening and why
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: The outlook for AI weather prediction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02084-9

Two models demonstrate the enormous potential that artificial intelligence holds for weather prediction. But the risks involved demand that meteorologists learn to design, evaluate and interpret such systems.
item.dc:title: The outlook for AI weather prediction
item.dc:creator: Imme Ebert-Uphoff
Kyle Hilburn

item.title: Author Correction: Cyclin-dependent kinase 12 is a drug target for visceral leishmaniasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06364-2

Author Correction: Cyclin-dependent kinase 12 is a drug target for visceral leishmaniasis
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Cyclin-dependent kinase 12 is a drug target for visceral leishmaniasis

item.title: Anti-ageing protein injection boosts monkeys’ memories
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02214-3

First primate studies to show cognitive benefits of the protein klotho could be a step towards clinical applications.
item.dc:title: Anti-ageing protein injection boosts monkeys’ memories
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

Nature, Published online: 04 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02134-2

Preparedness for drought is more than a climate-change fix

Felipe Arreguín

Snippets from Nature’s past.

Nature, Published online: 04 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02132-4

Enlightened Indian science tradition is not entering a dark age

item.title: France’s short-haul flight ban to tackle carbon emissions

Nature, Published online: 04 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02133-3

France’s short-haul flight ban to tackle carbon emissions

item.title: Carbon removal: avoid selective analysis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02131-5

Carbon removal: avoid selective analysis
item.dc:title: Carbon removal: avoid selective analysis
item.dc:creator: Rob Bellamy

item.title: Viruses trick bystander cells into lowering their defences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02135-1

The microenvironment of virus-infected cells and uninfected adjacent cells influences infection. Human cytomegalovirus dampens the immune response of neighbouring uninfected cells, but distant cells can mount an antiviral defence.
item.dc:title: Viruses trick bystander cells into lowering their defences
item.dc:creator: Timothy M. White
Felicia D. Goodrum

item.title: Lab-grown meat: the science of turning cells into steaks and nuggets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02095-6

Companies making cultured meat are attracting billions of dollars of investment. Here are their biggest challenges.
item.dc:title: Lab-grown meat: the science of turning cells into steaks and nuggets
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Fungi bacon and insect burgers: a guide to the proteins of the future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02096-5

Humanity needs to eat less meat. Here are seven alternatives.
item.dc:title: Fungi bacon and insect burgers: a guide to the proteins of the future
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Hunger and famine are not accidents — they are created by the actions of people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02207-2

Hundreds of millions of people are going hungry as conflicts affect food supplies. There is also growing evidence that food producers are exploiting the situation to increase their profits.
item.dc:title: Hunger and famine are not accidents — they are created by the actions of people

The month’s sharpest science shots — selected by Nature’s photo team.

item.title: This activist-academic has a passion for podcasts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02137-z

Anthropologist Nosipho Mngomezulu finds podcasting an authentic, immediate way to reach an audience.
item.dc:title: This activist-academic has a passion for podcasts
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: How ancient monkeys rode the waves to the Americas — and survived
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02145-z

Analysis suggests that three types of primate made the transoceanic journey to South America from Africa millions of years ago.
item.dc:title: How ancient monkeys rode the waves to the Americas — and survived

item.title: How pandemic lockdowns changed workplace friendships
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02210-7

Hybrid work environments have altered how we connect with colleagues. But building work friendships can protect against burnout and make you more productive.
item.dc:title: How pandemic lockdowns changed workplace friendships
item.dc:creator: Lola Brown
Ruth Gotian

item.title: COVID-19 digital contact tracing worked — heed the lessons for future pandemics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02130-6

For all the controversy over decentralized contact-tracing apps, data show that these privacy-preserving tools saved thousands of lives during the pandemic. National and international authorities must invest in the technology now.
item.dc:title: COVID-19 digital contact tracing worked — heed the lessons for future pandemics
item.dc:creator: Marcel Salathé

item.title: US Supreme Court on affirmative action: a bitter blow to educational inclusion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02206-3

The highest US court’s decision that race cannot be considered in university admissions risks rolling back what little progress has been made on racial equity in the sector.
item.dc:title: US Supreme Court on affirmative action: a bitter blow to educational inclusion

item.title: Preprints become papers less often when the authors are from lower-income countries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02216-1

A lack of financial resources is likely to be one of the key factors preventing the transition.
item.dc:title: Preprints become papers less often when the authors are from lower-income countries
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: Why economic crashes boost globalization — and tear it apart
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02129-z

Responses to financial crashes, pandemics and other crises spur progress, through cycles of inward and outward change.
item.dc:title: Why economic crashes boost globalization — and tear it apart
item.dc:creator: Mark Buchanan

item.title: A robotic raspberry teaches machines how to pick fruit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02173-9

This fake raspberry allows researchers to train fruit-picking robots in the lab before field tests.
item.dc:title: A robotic raspberry teaches machines how to pick fruit
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: First glimpses inside octopus’s sleeping brains reveals human-like patterns
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02198-0

Neural activity show an ‘active’ sleep stage similar to REM sleep in mammals.
item.dc:title: First glimpses inside octopus’s sleeping brains reveals human-like patterns
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Audio long read: ‘Almost magical’ — chemists can now move single atoms in and out of a molecule’s core
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02081-y

Methods to insert, swap or delete atoms in the backbones of molecules could transform medicinal chemistry.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: ‘Almost magical’ — chemists can now move single atoms in and out of a molecule’s core
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Tasmanian devil cancer vaccine approved for testing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02124-4

The vaccine was inspired by COVID jabs, but if it is approved, it will be delivered in edible bait.
item.dc:title: Tasmanian devil cancer vaccine approved for testing
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: How to train early-career scientists to weather failure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02168-6

Workshops and training programmes tackle failure and how to recover from it.
item.dc:title: How to train early-career scientists to weather failure
item.dc:creator: Laurie Udesky

item.title: Mini-antibodies given mighty powers can stave off influenza
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02090-x

Complexes formed from ‘nanobodies’ and an antiviral drug halt infection in its tracks.
item.dc:title: Mini-antibodies given mighty powers can stave off influenza

item.title: Giant gravitational waves: why scientists are so excited
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02203-6

Astrophysicists describe what galaxy-wide gravitational waves could mean for our understanding of black holes and the history of the cosmos.
item.dc:title: Giant gravitational waves: why scientists are so excited
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Euclid launch: dark-energy mapper poised to probe cosmic mysteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02194-4

The European craft could help to investigate why the Universe’s expansion is accelerating, along with other cosmic questions.
item.dc:title: Euclid launch: dark-energy mapper poised to probe cosmic mysteries
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Australia to prescribe MDMA and psilocybin for PTSD and depression in world first
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02093-8

Decision to make the previously illicit drugs available is dogged by suggestions that it was rushed.
item.dc:title: Australia to prescribe MDMA and psilocybin for PTSD and depression in world first
item.dc:creator: Rich Haridy

item.title: These six distant galaxies captured by JWST are wowing astronomers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02157-9

See researchers’ favourites from a survey of the deep Universe by the James Webb Space Telescope.
item.dc:title: These six distant galaxies captured by JWST are wowing astronomers
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Daily briefing: Australia will be first to prescribe these psychedelics as medicines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02211-6

MDMA and psilocybin can now be prescribed by approved psychiatrists in Australia. Plus, US Supreme Court ends affirmative action at universities and what we need to know about the El Niño weather event.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Australia will be first to prescribe these psychedelics as medicines
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Postdoctoral researchers warn NIH that cost-of-living pressures are gutting the workforce
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02202-7

Pay and benefits top the list of concerns identified by US working group.
item.dc:title: Postdoctoral researchers warn NIH that cost-of-living pressures are gutting the workforce
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: El Niño is here — how bad will it be?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02122-6

The strong climate pattern could push global temperatures to record highs.
item.dc:title: El Niño is here — how bad will it be?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: US to end race-based university admissions: what now for diversity in science?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01900-6

Researchers talk to Nature about how halting race-conscious admissions will affect STEM employment, university applications and more.
item.dc:title: US to end race-based university admissions: what now for diversity in science?
item.dc:creator: Helen Santoro

item.title: Foldseek gives AlphaFold protein database a rapid search tool
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02205-4

The structural search program makes finding proteins with similar 3D shapes easy.
item.dc:title: Foldseek gives AlphaFold protein database a rapid search tool
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson
